programme.title: The Antarctica Challenge - A Global Warning
programme.desc: Filmmaker Mark Terry leads an expedition to Antarctica to report on the new discoveries made by the world’s scientific community stationed in Antarctica during International Polar Years (March, 2007 to March, 2009). This award-winning documentary will provide support interviews from polar experts and research scientists around the world as well as rare footage of wildlife. It reveals many startling new scientific revelations such as penguin suicide, new vegetation growing in the world’s largest desert, diminishing populations of land animals and marine life and the dangerously increasing melting of Antarctica’s land ice. These new discoveries were considered so valuable that this film became the only one invited by the United Nations tom screen to world leaders during the Climate Change Conference in Copenhagen, December, 2009.

programme.title: Expedition to Eternal Ice
programme.desc: In the spring of 1930, when Alfred Wegener sets off on his third Greenland expedition, he hopes it will be the crowning glory of his career. Just a few years earlier he created a furore when he published his theory of continental drift; now he intends to revolutionise climatic research. For a whole year he and his team will compile data from high in the atmosphere and deep in the ice sheet. This is to be the first long-term climatic study ever carried out, and it marks the beginning of modern climatic research. Some of the scientists will venture far into the interior of the country and even set up a research station on the ice. This, the aptly named Inland Ice, will be 400 km away from the base camp on the West Coast, and specially constructed motorised propeller sleds will be used to transport not only the construction materials for the station but also provisions to see them through the long winter. Wegener has planned the expedition meticulously, down to the tiniest detail – but things don't turn out as he hoped. Right at the start the weather upsets his calculations. He loses six valuable weeks, and it then emerges that the propeller sleds don't work properly. They will have to resort to dog sleds for all their transportation needs. Despite the unfavourable circumstances, the scientists begin work in the middle of the ice sheet… even though they don't have enough provisions for the winter. Supplies are to be brought out to them later, but then the weather takes a dramatic turn for the worse, and Alfred Wegener and his men are faced with a race against time, their very lives at stake. A race they will ultimately lose.

programme.title: Penguin Central
programme.desc: In four very different locations in southern New Zealand four species of penguin parents begin their annual breeding season. In the south west corner of the south island in the rugged wilderness of Fiordland National Park, where dramatic fiords provide a magnificent setting, Fiordland crested penguin mates reunite in the middle of winter to begin their courtship.

programme.title: Mammoths - Giants of the Ice Age
programme.desc: Of all extinct creatures, the mammoth surely exerts the greatest fascination for us. This ARTE documentary shows how these prehistoric forefathers of the elephant came into being, conquered half the globe but finally had to give way to a new era in the history of our planet.

programme.title: To the South
programme.desc: At the first part of his journey, the photographer is lucky to get some shots of rare animal species. Between the gaps of the rocky mountains he traces funny creatures: Pica. They look like a mixture between hamsters and rabbits. From his hideout Benny Rebel manages to observe impressive Ibexes, a kind of wild goats with huge horns.

programme.title: To the North
programme.desc: Benny Rebel approaches a big cat in the semi desert with caution. An Asiatic cheetah is like an icon of Iranian nature. The carnivore accepts Benny in its closer environment. The photographer takes breath taking shots. Rewarded in this way Rebel continues his challenging expedition in a high mood.

programme.title: Coasts
programme.desc: A cat shark out hunting, guillemots fearlessly jumping from the cliffs of Helgoland, the birth of a snow-white baby seal: the 2,400km of German coastlines are home to a unique diversity of species. Over thousands of years, the slow current of the North Sea has allowed silt to accumulate and form the unique world of the Wadden Sea, a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 2009.

programme.title: Mountains
programme.desc: A mother lynx feeds on freshly caught prey with her cubs, agile chamoix leap along mountain ledges, bee-eaters dig nesting holes in vineyards, black storks bring up their young on narrow ridges.

programme.title: To the South
programme.desc: At the first part of his journey, the photographer is lucky to get some shots of rare animal species. Between the gaps of the rocky mountains he traces funny creatures: Pica. They look like a mixture between hamsters and rabbits. From his hideout Benny Rebel manages to observe impressive Ibexes, a kind of wild goats with huge horns.

programme.title: To the North
programme.desc: Benny Rebel approaches a big cat in the semi desert with caution. An Asiatic cheetah is like an icon of Iranian nature. The carnivore accepts Benny in its closer environment. The photographer takes breath taking shots. Rewarded in this way Rebel continues his challenging expedition in a high mood.

programme.title: Dolphins and Whales
programme.desc: Ute Margreff lives on the rough Atlantic coast of Ireland, while Florian Graner has settled in the fjord region in the north-west of the USA. Both originally from Germany, they have never met, but they are united by one thing: a passion for the sea and its inhabitants.

programme.title: Molas and Manatees
programme.desc: The ocean occupies more than two-thirds of our planet's surface, constituting an extreme habitat with dimensions beyond our comprehension and a variety of lifeforms that can scarcely be chronicled. It is in the seven seas that we find the last "white spaces" of our world: unexplored, mysterious expanses still virtually off-limits to human beings – although that doesn't stop us recklessly plundering and destroying these areas.

programme.title: 300 Million Years - Season 1
programme.desc: 300 Million Years – Part One relates the dramatic history of how the continent of Europe came to be – from the carboniferous period to the extinction of the dinosaurs 65 million years ago. How did the continent we call Europe come to be? Many years passed before it began to look like it does today.

programme.title: 300 Million Years - Season 1
programme.desc: In the subsequent 65 million years, mammals dominate the history of the European continent. Sea mammals conquered the oceans while large herds of herbivores crisscrossed the forests and plains. The conditions of life changed suddenly 2.6 million years ago, and a new era began.

programme.title: Origins and Identity
programme.desc: Where and when does the history of Europe begin? The traces lead to ancient Greece, more precisely to Crete: Here we not only found the first high culture of the continent, but also the founding myth, to which it owes its name: The story of the kidnapping of the Phoenician princess Europa by the Greek god father Zeus.

programme.title: Beliefs and Ideas
programme.desc: For many Europeans, Europe today is synonymous with the "Christian Occident". But like so much of what has shaped our civilization, Christianity also comes from the Orient. And it is not the only "one-faith belief" that shapes the continent: even before Christianity, Judaism spread throughout the Roman Empire.

programme.title: Europe in the Middle Ages
programme.desc: Picturesque castles, noble knights, minnesingers and troubadours - these romantic images fire our imagination in the generally accepted conception of the Middle Ages. On the darker side of this world, there are gloomy castle dungeons, torture chambers and bloody raids and power struggles.

programme.title: Europe in the Middle Ages
programme.desc: As centres of missionary activity and science, monasteries made an important contribution to progress. Here, not only theology was taught and studied, but medicine, mathematics, astronomy, law and philosophy as well. With the translation of the ancient scripts into Latin, this knowledge was introduced to the western world.

programme.title: Dolphins and Whales
programme.desc: Ute Margreff lives on the rough Atlantic coast of Ireland, while Florian Graner has settled in the fjord region in the north-west of the USA. Both originally from Germany, they have never met, but they are united by one thing: a passion for the sea and its inhabitants.

programme.desc: The ocean occupies more than two-thirds of our planet's surface, constituting an extreme habitat with dimensions beyond our comprehension and a variety of lifeforms that can scarcely be chronicled. It is in the seven seas that we find the last "white spaces" of our world: unexplored, mysterious expanses still virtually off-limits to human beings – although that doesn't stop us recklessly plundering and destroying these areas.

programme.title: 300 Million Years - Season 1
programme.desc: 300 Million Years – Part One relates the dramatic history of how the continent of Europe came to be – from the carboniferous period to the extinction of the dinosaurs 65 million years ago. How did the continent we call Europe come to be? Many years passed before it began to look like it does today.

programme.title: 300 Million Years - Season 1
programme.desc: In the subsequent 65 million years, mammals dominate the history of the European continent. Sea mammals conquered the oceans while large herds of herbivores crisscrossed the forests and plains. The conditions of life changed suddenly 2.6 million years ago, and a new era began.

programme.title: The Story of Europe
programme.desc: Europe's history has many dark sides, but its culture is more than a small gleam of hope, it radiates in many areas far out into the world. The old continent sets standards in art, literature and science. Starting with the ancient Greeks, Europe produces a number of smart and creative minds: from Aristotle to Michelangelo and Einstein, from Beethoven to the Beatles.

programme.title: The Story of Europe
programme.desc: Europe has been a battle concept for centuries: it often takes foreign enemies to weld the Europeans together. But for centuries, they are primarily fighting against themselves. It was not until the Enlightenment and the French Revolution of 1789 that a new idea of Europe emerged based on common values: freedom, equality and fraternalism.

programme.title: China's Schindlers
programme.desc: These are two stories rarely told that should never be forgotten: The stories of China’s Schindlers - two courageous men who stood up for human decency as evil engulfed the world. Chinese diplomat Dr. Feng Shan Ho was Consul-General in Vienna, Austria in the late 1930s. Disturbed by the Nazis’ persecution of Viennese Jews, Feng Shan Ho gave visas to Jews desperate enough to escape Hitler, and that allowed them to immigrate to Shanghai when no other nation would accept them. German businessman John Rabe lived in China for 30 years. In 1937, after Japanese troops invaded his adopted city of Nanking, Rabe could not bear to witness the horrors and atrocities around him. Under the protection of the Nazi flag, he led the establishment of a Safety Zone protecting 200,000 innocent Chinese. Diaries & letters left behind are among some of the only evidence left of those who endured unspeakable horrors and bravely sacrificed for their fellow man. Those diaries, along with the voices of survivors tell not only of the darkness and terror, but also of the heroism, bravery and sacrifice of a few individuals whose character and courage stand as beacons of the human spirit. We illustrate the complex nature of the political positions of Germany, Japan, and China during WWII, highlighting Germany's acknowledgement of its wartime actions in an effort to heal relationships with the Jewish people and other neighboring countries. Experts discuss the positive impact that this has had on Germany socially and economically and how this strategy could benefit the Japanese and Chinese economic partnership and promote friendship in future generations. The West often overlooks China in the story of WWII. The Chinese people suffered horrors and atrocities that still haunt survivors. They bear witness to past brutality and endure emotional wounds that have never healed.
